summary.body: The language in what follows is not mine.  I have taken it straight from the back right hand side of the newly-distributed PODIUM which claims - in its stap line - to be "From the Barbican Centre for Residents".  It is death by a thousand cuts (taken in conjunction with all the other development works around and invading the quality of life of the Estate) and written in the kind of jargon that makes NEWSPEAK warm, cuddly and comprehensible. "As part of the Frobisher Redevelopment works, staff on Level 6 of the Barbican Centre are required to decant to other office spaces. The majority of Level 6 staff will be moving to a temporary site in Bonhill Street and the remainder, who cannot leave the site due to the nature of their work, will be located in two modular buildings located on the Sculpture Court." "The delivery of the modular buildings is currently scheduled for Sunday 18 November. The delivery is certified as an abnormal load, due to its size, therefore the Metropolitan Police will only allow this to take place overnight or on a Sunday. With the residents in mind, the Barbican Centre did want want the delivery to be overnight and therefore Sunday was chosen as the only other option." For those of you old enough to remember BEYOND THE FRINGE in 1961 you may already hear the cackle of Dudley Moore in the background as I continue in my best Alan Bennett (or Peter Cook or Jonathan Miller voice) because this piece of idiocy would have been fought over by all the cast as it is such a gem. "It is necessary to close Silk Street to allow the delivery to take place; road closure will be between the hours of 9am and 6pm. The modular buildings will then be craned into the Sculpture Court." "The mobile crane will arrive on Silk Street at 8am and will be set up in preparation for the first lift at 9am. Units will then be unpacked and attached to the crane which will lift the unit from Silk Street on to Level 3. Power pallet trucks will then be used to skate the units into position on the Sculpture Court." "There will be a total of 14 lifts taking place throughout the day and they will take approximately five minutes each....To address the environmental issue of noise, delivery vehicles will switch off engines between arrival and departure and the crane's engine will be switched off when not in operation." I've checked my blood pressure. Yes....it is up.  I do not want to use bad language on this site so I will let others scream the words for me as they read this (or as they react to the PODIUM delivery through their letterboxes). The convenient fiction - and it is one the City of London and our representatives on it to go along with -  seems to be that people do not live in the Barbican Estate, not really. And - if they do - then they bugger off at the weekend. And for those who stay then "Hey, you'll wish you hadn't." The interest I declare - in this posting - is that, living in a flat in Shakespeare looking out over the Sculpture Court, means that Calypso and I will have to live through the stated (and probably under-estimated)14 lifts on that Sunday and we are being treated as if we were not here and shouldn't be here.  The trouble is it makes me want to hire a mobile crane and some modular buildings and to go and spend a weekend - maybe over the Christmas/New Year period of goodwill - doing exactly this close to the people who think this is OK....but that way lies madness, war and the destruction of civilisation.  I'd better get back in my box and keep taking the tablets.
summary.subject: Just when you thought it was safe to sleep in

summary.body: I am in the process of buying a flat in John Trundle, and my solicitor made some enquiries with crossrail. What came back was a non specific letter, which told me nothing I am going to attach the letter at the end of the mail. My question is, has anyone in the same block had any more useful information than this, and is the possibility of structural damage a real possibility. Thanks Max Thank you for your enquiry of 9 December 2005 regarding the effect of Crossrail on the above property.  Cross London Rail Links Limited administers a Direction issued by the Department of Transport on 22 February 2005 for the Safeguarding of the preferred alignment of Crossrail. The Secretary of State for Transport has introduced a Bill into Parliament that if enacted would authorise acquisition of the land and construction of the project. The Bill is expected to take about 2 years to be approved, which will include an examination of the proposals and objections to them in public before two Parliamentary Committees. Construction could start in 2008 and take about 6 years.  You may inspect and/or purchase copies of Plans, Sections, Environmental Statement, Explanatory Notes and Non-Technical Summary regarding the Crossrail Proposals at specified Libraries and Local Authority Offices.  The proposed route of Crossrail runs from Shenfield to Stratford, descending into a tunnel at Bow. The line will continue through Whitechapel, Liverpool Street, Farringdon, Tottenham Court Road, Bond Street and Paddington, and continue on the surface to Heathrow and Maidenhead.  The property falls within the consultation limits shown on the plans attached to the Safeguarding Direction. The terms of the Direction require the local authority to consult Cross London Rail Links Limited regarding planning applications that are within the limits of consultation. The local planning authority is required to report to the Secretary of State for Transport if it resolves to determine the application in a manner which is inconsistent with the advice given by Crossrail.  It is Crossrail policy to limit damage to buildings as a result of settlement to slight (as defined by the work of Burland et al 1977 and Boscardin and Cording 1989), if necessary by carrying out engineering protective works.  We currently anticipate that properties located within the zone of settlement will be surveyed by independent building surveyors and a schedule of existing defects prepared.  Should any claim subsequently be made in respect of damage to the building caused by the construction of the works it will be considered against this initial survey and schedule.  Compensation will be payable in respect of any justifiable claims for damage so caused, in accordance with compensation law and practice.  With regard to operational noise, the underground sections of Crossrail are being designed with the aim that re-radiated noise levels inside buildings will not exceed a maximum sound level of 40dB(A).  In most underground areas the trains will run on continuous welded track supported on resilient base plates, which will help to reduce any adverse noise and vibration levels considerably.  If redevelopment is being considered, Crossrail would advise that a meeting be arranged with its engineers as soon as possible to discuss the impact of foundations, basements and other structures (including piles) on Crossrails proposed structures and tunnels, including ground movement arising from the construction thereof and the effects of noise and vibration.  I hope this information is helpful, but if you require any further assistance then please feel free to contact me.
summary.subject: crossrail letter

summary.body: For those of you who are interested in what was on the school site in previous centuries, I've been doing some more research and found out the following. In the late 18th century a brewery called the Goat Brewhouse was operating. A 20 year old called Sam Whitbread starting working there, then moved to Whitbread's present site within a few years. By 1813 the Whitecross St site was a debtors' prison! It was built to separate debtors from the other prisoners who were held in Newgate, so that they (the debtors) wouldn't be led astray by hardened criminals. The medieval Jewish cemetery was further south than I thought and probably stretched from Thomas More Gardens up to Beech Street.   The dig under the marquee seems to have been completed now, although the soil being replaced is being sifted through, but there's a smaller dig opened up nearer Whitecross. No idea what's there.
summary.subject: A little more local history

summary.body: Has anyone else received a letter from Crossrail?  It provides no comfort (in fact the opposite) to my mind... It is unclear whether the work site on Aldersgate Street will be required if the crossover cavern is to be built in a different way from that currently proposed.  The letter implies that it is. The working hours stated in the letter are not quite the whole story - it does not mention that working could also happen at weekends and at night (set out below) effectively at the discretion of the contractor.  The removal of spoil from the tunnel will take place on a   basis. Also the noise mitigation, which basically involves fitting double glazing   (!) inside our windows (and fitting a fan) is entirely unacceptable.  Apart from turning our flats into squalid non-ventilated greenhouses, I very much doubt that this is appropriate treatment for a Grade 2 listed building.   I for one am not prepared to live for 3 years without fresh air, and I also think what is proposed would be entirely impossible to install in our flat. BA Chair, we need you to organise us to oppose this. If we do not act together, I shall be certainly taking legal advice, but a joint approach would seem to me to make much more sense.  Normal working hours are planned to be from 0700 to 1900 on weekdays and 0700 to 1400 on Saturday. Only non-disruptive preparatory work, repairs or maintenance will be carried out on Saturday afternoons or Sundays between 0800 and 1700. The nominated undertaker will adhere to these normal working hours for each site as far as reasonably practicable and where feasible, operations anticipated to cause disturbance would be limited to these hours. There are certain exceptions to the normal working hours, which are described below. Certain operations are season and weather dependent and in these instances the nominated undertaker will seek, as is customary in the construction industry, to extend the working hours for such operations to take advantage of daylight hours, with the agreement of the relevant authorities.  Track laying and internal fit out works within the stations and tunnels may also be carried out on a 24 hour per day, 7 days per week basis. In order to safeguard the works it may be necessary for certain items of plant and equipment to be kept running 24 hours per day, which would include pumps and generators. Any such equipment will be shielded in order to provide appropriate noise attenuation. Staff may be required to collect data and samples outside normal working hours at times. Certain works requiring temporary possession of roads and railways for safety or operational requirements, to limit disruption to the travelling public, and works in connection with utilities when demand is low will need to be undertaken outside normal working hours. This will include Saturday afternoon, night-time, Sunday and/or bank holiday working from time to time. On occasion longer term possessions (in excess of one week) will be required for more major works.
